required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility and Practice Characteristics of FNS and Gait Robot
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility and Practice Characteristics of FNS and Gait Robot

lead_sponsor.agency: VA Office of Research and Development

clinical_study.source: VA Office of Research and Development

brief_summary.textblock:
Conventional therapies do not restore normal gait for many stroke survivors. The long-term goal of this work is to restore volitional lower limb motor control and gait following stroke. In our prior work, we demonstrated that it was feasible to provide a clinically operated, combined treatment of body weight supported treadmill training alone (BWSTT) + functional neuromuscular stimulation (FNS) using intramuscular (IM) electrodes (FNS-IM).
Specific Aims and Hypothesis The purpose or Specific Aim of the study is to test the feasibility and gait training potential of combining the Lokomat and FNS-IM for stroke survivors. Given the feasibility of our clinically operated combination of BWSTT + FNS-IM, we propose to test the feasibility of the combination of Lokomat + FNS-IM.
Hypothesis I. It is feasible to utilize a clinically operated combination of Lokomat + functional neuromuscular stimulation (FNS) with intramuscular (IM) electrodes (FNS-IM).
Treatment Procedures. The subjects will be treated for three months, four sessions/week (for a total of 48 treatment visits). A given session will be 1 hrs, with the time divided into thirds as follows: 1) hr coordination exercise; 2) hr over ground gait training; and 3) hr Lokomat gait training. FNS-IM will be used in all three aspects of the protocol, unless the subject is capable of volitionally executing a given movement or gait component. Population. The subjects will be chronic stroke survivors (>6 months after the stroke).

primary_outcome.measure: Observational Gait Components: Observational Comparison of Gait Components for: Gait Robot-alone Condition, FES-alone Condition, and Combined Gait Robot and FES.
primary_outcome.description: Observational Gait components during stance and swing phase, for pelvis, hip, knee, and ankle for each of the six participants was observed during the following conditions: Gait Robot-alone, FES-alone, and combined Gait Robot and FES.

intervention.description: gait training with the use of a gait robot

intervention.intervention_name: Functional Neuromuscular stimulation with intramuscular electrodes
intervention.description: gait training with use of functional electrical stimulation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Greater than or equal to 6 months after stroke
- 21 years or older
- Ability to follow 2 step commands
- Inability to move leg normally
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pacemaker
- Progressive medical condition (i.e. Parkinsons Disease)

results_reference.citation: McCabe JP, Dohring ME, Marsolais EB, Rogers J, Burdsall R, Roenigk K, Pundik S, Daly JJ. Feasibility of combining gait robot and multichannel functional electrical stimulation with intramuscular electrodes. J Rehabil Res Dev. 2008;45(7):997-1006.

Dohring ME, Daly JJ. Automatic synchronization of functional electrical stimulation and robotic assisted treadmill training. IEEE Trans Neural Syst Rehabil Eng. 2008 Jun;16(3):310-3. doi: 10.1109/TNSRE.2008.920081.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were recruited through use of advertisement and by word of mouth to enter this feasibility study.

group.title: Gait Training After Stroke
group.description: Subjects with chronic stroke (.5-1.5 years post stroke) received gait training with the use of functional neuromuscular stimulation with intramuscular electrodes and gait robot.

baseline.population: This was a feasibility study of six subjects. Sample size was constrained by funding limit.

group.title: Gait Training After Stroke
group.description: Subjects with chronic stroke (.5-1.5 years post stroke) received gait training with the use of functional neuromuscular stimulation with intramuscular electrodes and gait robot.

outcome.title: Observational Gait Components: Observational Comparison of Gait Components for: Gait Robot-alone Condition, FES-alone Condition, and Combined Gait Robot and FES.
outcome.description: Observational Gait components during stance and swing phase, for pelvis, hip, knee, and ankle for each of the six participants was observed during the following conditions: Gait Robot-alone, FES-alone, and combined Gait Robot and FES.
outcome.population: The sample size for this feasibility study was n=6, constrained by funding limit.

group.title: Gait Robot-alone Training
group.description: The 6 study subjects with chronic stroke ambulated in the Gait Robot, and observational gait analysis was performed.

group.title: FES-Alone
group.description: The 6 study subjects with chronic stroke ambulated with FES, and observational gait analysis was performed.

group.title: Combined Gait Robot and FES
group.description: The 6 study subjects with chronic stroke ambulated with combination Gait Robot and FES, and observational gait analysis was performed.

measure.title: Observational Gait Components: Observational Comparison of Gait Components for: Gait Robot-alone Condition, FES-alone Condition, and Combined Gait Robot and FES.
measure.description: Observational Gait components during stance and swing phase, for pelvis, hip, knee, and ankle for each of the six participants was observed during the following conditions: Gait Robot-alone, FES-alone, and combined Gait Robot and FES.
measure.population: The sample size for this feasibility study was n=6, constrained by funding limit.

class.title: allowed for ankle movement in sagittal plane

group.title: Gait Training After Stroke
group.description: subjects with Chronic stroke (.5-1.5 years post stroke)received gait training with the use of functional neuromuscular stimulation with intramuscular electrodes and Gait Robot.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This was a feasibility study to determine the possibility of combining two technologies. Further study of the combined treatment is needed to determine whether the feasible combined treatment is more effective than other methods.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Janis Daly, Ph.D., M.S.; Director, Brain Rehabilitation Research Center of Excellence
point_of_contact.organization: Malcom Randall VA Medical Center, Gainesville Florida
